title: A question about Jhinn...
body: ...so exactly how is the gun ironic?

replies.body: The gun is name whisper and guns are loud

i know this all too well 

when i first played him when he came on to live servers i am sitting in lane waiting for minions and i decide to read his skills and saw that it said his guns name is whisper and i literally said to myself hmm thats ironic (considering that his autos sound so loud and satisfying) 

and you can probably guess what quote he was generated to say next which freaked me out

Could I Add to the questions? I never got to ask. But does Jhin have a sense of morality? Say one of his targets was a mere child. Would he refuse the contract? Or could he control himself if he was feeling "inspired" And there happens to be a family near.....

Jhin strikes me as something of a nihilist. I think even if he were able to feel pity, which is debatable, mercy would be entirely out of the question. One wouldn't last long in his line of work with a sense of mercy, and certainly wouldn't achieve the sort of greatness Jhin pursues in his art.

Oh. For some reason I assumed there was some heady philosophical statement being made. Actually on that subject, his quote about there being nothing else for him but killing... is this just a declaration of his fixation, or also a reference to the understanding that the people who released him would see him dead if he ever stopped doing their dirty work for them? I remember hearing a Rioter state that there would be more insight into why Jhin is the way he is in future lore releases, and I'm really looking forward to that.

From what we know about Jhin,he actually seems to be highly depressive and killing is the only thing that brings him joy,so I'd say that statement is more focused on his fixation(I mean his lore even implies that jhin will likely betray his superiors eventually and start doing his own thing again)
How do you mean? Do you mean in the sense of a  killing implement having such a glaring shortcoming for the purpose of being more dramatic and flashy?
Well, that and 4 is his recurring number. It's something to do with it being unlucky in Asia, I'm not sure.

Yeah the word for "4" in I believe both Japanese AND Chinese is uncannily similar to the word for "Death". So 4 is considered sort of a cursed number. Not entirely unlike 13 in the west, but definitely with more ominous associations.

For some reason I figured the irony must either be that he was using a weapon that was intentionally inefficient to kill, when proper killing is itself an exercise in efficiency; or else that it had something to do with the association of guns with power, while he himself consciously recognizes his own powerlessness in his situation, in the sense that he is a pawn doing the bidding of others, and also in the sense that he cannot choose to be anything other than what he is. 

Maybe I'm reading way too much into it though.

And Korea.

Did not know that. Japan and China make sense because Japan essentially jacked the Chinese alphabet. So much so that to this day, Kanji can be read in either the chinese or japanese interpretation, and context is crucial in determining which is appropriate when. Or at least, that's my understanding of the situation. Korea too though? I don't really know the extent to which their culture and history are interrelated with their neighbors. Can't say I really know an awful lot about Korea tbh.

Yeah, Korea has two number systems; Syno-Korean derived from China, and pure Korean. They each have their own uses. However, people in Korea are still superstitious about the number 4, and on elevator, oftentimes they don't put the number 4.
